abstract.p: Jane Giles reviews novel Sirena Selena by Mayra Santos-Febres (S)

block.p: In her lush and tragicomic first novel, the Puerto Rican writer Mayra Santos-Febres recounts the transformation of a 15-year-old gay street hustler with a golden voice into a diva known as Sirena Selena. Martha Divine, a veteran drag queen on the San Juan gay scene, rescues the boy from the gutter, makes sure he has a few chanteuse-worthy gowns and takes him to perform at expensive hotels in the Dominican Republic, where Selena is discovered by Hugo Graubel, a wealthy businessman with an old secret. The novel oscillates between Selena's long (too long) seduction of Graubel, flashbacks to his life as a street youth, the stories of Martha Divine and the experiences of a Dominican boy whose life parallels Selena's own. Selena begins the novel as a real person with real problems, but by the end she is a remote, geishalike seductress, sidestepping the temptation of romantic love for the sake of survival. Santos-Febres is at her best when she blends lyrical hyperbole with social observation; the novel, adeptly translated by Stephen Lytle, loses some of its originality when it evokes the more commonplace stereotypes of gay culture or the Latin American telenovela. Its melodramatically comic voices evoke a life ''at war against nature,'' in which a delicate boy's transformation into ''woman'' ironically helps him evade seemingly inevitable violence. Santos-Febres examines questions of sexuality and power but does not lead her characters into a utopia: it's still all about who's got the money and who's on top.
